subject_question.title: Subject Questions
subject_question.content:
A Subject Question is a question that asks about the doer or performer of an action. The question word (like Who, What, or Which) is the subject of the sentence.

The key rule is that we do not use the auxiliary verbs (do, does, did) in simple present and simple past tenses. The sentence structure is like a normal statement.

Structure:

Question Word (Subject) + Main Verb + (Object/Rest of sentence)?

Examples:

  • Who implemented this feature? (We are asking for the 'who'.)
  • What causes this conflict? (We are asking for the 'what'.)
  • Which team has the latest code? (We are asking for the 'which team'.)

object_question.title: Object Questions
object_question.content:
An Object Question is a question that asks about the receiver of an action. The subject of the sentence is known, and the question word (like Who, What, or Which) asks about the object.

The key rule is that we must use the auxiliary verbs (do, does, did) in simple present and simple past tenses. The structure requires inversion.

Structure:

Question Word (Object) + Auxiliary Verb + Subject + Main Verb?

Examples:

  • What module did the team modify? (The team did something. We ask what.)
  • Who did you ask? (You asked someone. We ask who.)
  • Which report does this issue mention? (The issue mentions a report. We ask which one.)

phrasal_verbs.title: Phrasal Verbs
phrasal_verbs.content:
A Phrasal Verb is a combination of a standard verb (like 'get', 'take', 'come') and one or two particles (usually a preposition or adverb like 'up', 'on', 'away').

The meaning of the combination is often very different from the meaning of the individual words. They are extremely common in informal English.

Examples:

  • Take care of: to deal with or handle something.
  • Come up: to happen unexpectedly.
  • Run into: to encounter or meet someone/something by chance.

false_friends.title: False Friends
false_friends.content:
False Friends (or 'false cognates') are words in two different languages that look or sound similar, but have different meanings.

They are a common source of mistakes for learners. It is important to learn them to avoid misunderstandings.

Examples:

  • Assist (English) vs. Asistir (Spanish): 'Assist' means to help, while 'asistir' means to attend.
  • Library (English) vs. Librería (Spanish): 'Library' is a place to borrow books (biblioteca), while 'librería' is a bookstore.
  • Embarrassed (English) vs. Embarazada (Spanish): 'Embarrassed' means feeling ashamed, while 'embarazada' means pregnant.

make_vs_do.title: Make vs. Do
make_vs_do.content:
Do and Make are two verbs that are often confused. The general rule is:

  • Use Do for actions, obligations, and repetitive tasks. It focuses on the process of acting. (e.g., do homework, do a job, do chores).
  • Use Make for creating, constructing, or producing something new that wasn't there before. It focuses on the result. (e.g., make a cake, make a decision, make a sound).

When in doubt, it's often best to learn them as fixed expressions.

modal_verbs_future.title: Modal Verbs: Future Tense
modal_verbs_future.content:
Modal verbs like can, must, and may do not have future tense forms on their own. You cannot say 'will can' or 'will must'.

To express these ideas in the future, we use their equivalent phrasal forms.

Common Equivalents:

  • Future of can (ability) → will be able to.
  • Future of must (obligation) → will have to.

Example:

~I will can join the meeting.~ (Incorrect)
I will be able to join the meeting. (Correct)

possessive_nouns.title: Possessive Nouns
possessive_nouns.content:
To show that something belongs to a noun, we usually add an apostrophe + s ('s). This is a very common and natural way to express possession in English.

This structure is often more idiomatic than using 'of the'.

Examples:

  • 'the meeting of tomorrow' → 'tomorrow's meeting'
  • 'the report of the issue' → 'the issue's report'
  • 'the car of my friend' → 'my friend's car'

For plural nouns that already end in -s, we just add an apostrophe: 'the developers' computers'.

prepositions_of_time.title: Prepositions of Time: On, In, At
prepositions_of_time.content:
Choosing the correct preposition for time expressions follows some general rules:

  • ON is used for specific days and dates.
    Example: on Friday, on my birthday, on July 4th.
  • IN is used for longer, non-specific periods like months, years, seasons, and decades.
    Example: in August, in 2025, in the summer.
  • AT is used for specific times of the day.
    Example: at 3:00 PM, at noon, at midnight.

adjective_vs_adverb.title: Adjective vs. Adverb
adjective_vs_adverb.content:
An adjective describes a noun (a person, place, or thing). A common example is good.

An adverb describes a verb (an action), an adjective, or another adverb. A common example is well.

Examples:

  • He is a good developer. ('good' describes the noun 'developer')
  • He develops well. ('well' describes the verb 'develops')

A frequent mistake is using 'good' to describe a verb: ~I understood it good.~ → I understood it well.

still_vs_yet.title: Still vs. Yet
still_vs_yet.content:
Both words can relate to time, but they are used in different types of sentences.

  • Still is used for an action that started in the past and continues into the present. It is almost always used in affirmative (positive) sentences.
    Example: We are still working on the issue.
  • Yet is used to talk about something that is expected to happen but hasn't happened. It is almost always used in negative sentences and questions.
    Example: We haven't fixed it yet. / Have you fixed it yet?

prepositions_for_vs_of.title: Prepositions: For vs. Of
prepositions_for_vs_of.content:
While both can be translated as 'de' in Spanish, their use in English is distinct.

  • Of is generally used to show possession or belonging.
    Example: The corner of the room. / The name of the file.
  • For is generally used to show purpose or reason.
    Example: A key for the door. / A fix for this issue.

The phrase 'the fix of this issue' sounds unnatural because the fix's purpose is to solve the issue. Therefore, 'the fix for this issue' is the correct and idiomatic choice.

question_formation_auxiliaries.title: Question Formation (with Auxiliaries)
question_formation_auxiliaries.content:
In English, most questions in the simple present and simple past require an auxiliary verb (like DO, DOES, or DID) before the subject. This is called inversion.

Structure:

(Wh- Word) + Auxiliary Verb + Subject + Main Verb (in base form)?

Examples:

  • ~What you think?~ → What do you think?
  • ~What kind of account you used?~ → What kind of account did you use?

Remember, the main verb always returns to its base form (e.g., 'use', not 'used') when an auxiliary is present.

subject_verb_agreement_questions.title: Subject-Verb Agreement in Questions
subject_verb_agreement_questions.content:
When forming questions with 'do' and 'does', the verb must agree with the subject.

  • Use DO for plural subjects (they, we), and for I and you.
    Example: Do these logs contain the data? ('logs' is plural)
  • Use DOES for third-person singular subjects (he, she, it).
    Example: Does this change apply to QA? ('change' is singular)

A common mistake is to look at the wrong noun. In 'the latest report of bugs', the subject is 'report' (singular), not 'bugs' (plural). So, the correct question is: 'Does the latest report...'

negative_questions.title: Negative Questions
negative_questions.content:
Negative questions are used to confirm something you think is true, or to express surprise. They are very common in conversation.

They are usually formed with a contracted auxiliary verb (e.g., Don't, Isn't, Shouldn't, Didn't) at the beginning.

Structure:

Negative Auxiliary + Subject + Main Verb?

Examples:

  • Don't you think this is too complex?
  • Shouldn't this feature be in production?
  • Didn't we fix this issue already?
